text: (pan sizzling)

- Hello and welcome to
another mystery box challenge.

This time it's our normal
home cook Barry's turn
to see if he can beat our chef, Ben.
We've challenged them to create a dish
celebrating an amazing mystery ingredient.
And this is them finding it out.
- [Ben] Olives.
- Get in, okay, right.
- [Ben] And oil?
- So olives.
- [Mike] Olive oil.
- Olive oil?

Cheers.
- We use that a lot.
We can do something cool with that.
- So ahead of the battle,
we thought we'd send them on a journey
to learn everything they can about olives,

how they're farmed and how
to get the most out of them
in their dishes,

starting with Kostas an
olive farmer in Greece.
- (speaking foreign language)

- Now my first question
is how do you farm olives?
- (speaking Greek)
- So Kostas, what type of olives
do you grow on your farm?
- (Greek)

- And the local variety,
Athenoia olive that you grow,

what are the characteristics,
what's it flavour like?
- (Greek)
- So growing olives in Greece, what is it

that makes the area so perfect
in terms of it's conditions.
- (Greek)
- So what sort of challenges do you face
as an olive farmer then?
- (Greek)

- [Mike] Next the guys
spoke to Marianna from BASF

to learn more about how farmers
and the agriculture industry

are working together to
increase sustainability
in their production.

- Now speaking to Kostas,
it sounds like as a farmer,
there's lots of things to juggle,
but what's one of the biggest challenges
of olive farming today?

- One of them is for sure that
we're a growing population.

I would say that another
one is that we have
very finite natural resources
and we have to make the most out of those
for a growing population.

And of course the whole
topic of climate change,
I think is very important as well,

because slowly you're
beginning to have more extreme

and adverse weather conditions
that are very quickly
inter-changing between each other,

so that's affecting
disease and pests as well.
But of course the important thing

is that we're here to,
I think, work together
to find a solution.
And we have to be optimistic with science
about the future and innovation.

This is what also the part
of the BASF farm network

is about, because we realise
we can't do things alone,
so you have to find the right partnerships
to be able to make a difference.

- Next up we sent the
boys to Borough Market,
to meet Marianna from Oliveology.
(upbeat music)
- Hi Marianna,

nice to meet you.
- Hi guys.
- I'm Ben, this is Barry.
- Welcome to Oliveology.
Nice to meet you.

We're gonna do some
olive oil tasting today,
but first we're gonna cleanse your palate
with some olive leaf tea.

- Yes.
- Olive tea?
- [Marianna] Olive leaf tea, yes.
- Oh that's beautiful.

- Olive oil and olives are
one of the key ingredients
of the Greek diet.

Everybody in Greece uses
extra virgin olive oil
for absolutely everything
from salads to roasting, grilling.

- [Ben] And the Mediterranean
diet is phenomenal.

- They're one of the
healthiest nations, absolutely,

and it's because they consume
so much olive oil and olives.
Actually our consumption is approximately
25 litres per person per year, so-
- That's like a bathtub.
- Sorry what?
- All of the olives have been handpicked,

hand selected, transported
to the olive press
within a few hours of being picked.

Pressed at a really
really cold temperature,

as low as 18 degrees,
which is extremely low
because you get so little yield

compared to what you would
have if you used temperatures
up to 27 degrees.

The olive oils are unfiltered
and then they are bottled
in these metal containers to protect them
from light and heat.
- So your farms are all organic
and you don't use pesticides.

What do you do to get
around the pest problem?

- Climate change has
been really challenging

for our producers, because the
changes in weather conditions
have encouraged a lot of pests.

Obviously the olive fly is
one of the most common pests,

but there are also about
30 more insects, viruses,

and other types of diseases
that have developed
over the last couple of years.

Sometimes for example you
use insects like ladybirds,
because ladybirds they like to eat

other types of insects
that are very damaging

to the olive fruit, or you
try to work with nature.
- So the biodiversity is important.
- Absolutely, absolutely.

- [Mike] Having learned
about the struggles

it's essential both guys create dishes
